body:
May be better to detect?
* Rotate-bbox (x,y,w,h,angle)
* or Rotated-3d-bbox (x,y,z,w,h,l,a1,a2,a3) 

This will be a more general solution for more tasks.
If you don't need some of these coords, then you just keep them `0`.


If you want to detect the **borders** of non-rectangular objects, then a more general solution would be - Instance Segmentation, like YOLACT++.

@LukeAI your idea is suboptimal because it needs to fit 8 parameters, when the simplest reduction of the parameter space would be 5: the existing 4 plus an angle like @AlexeyAB mentions. There are several implementations that do this, in particular for satellite imagery this can be very useful, as objects may have arbitrary rotations.

In any case, adding a 5th output to the yolo layer is trivial, what you need is properly labelled training data. The training data is always the bottleneck. If you have money and manpower to relabel your entire dataset with rotation info for each box then you are good to go.

A rectangular object rotated arbitrarily in 3d space could not be parameterised by less than 8 metrics, the 2D projection could be literally any quadrilateral. This is different to a rectangle rotated in 2D. Yes, as I say I have a large dataset of these objects already annotated - each object is defined by 4 (x,y) coordinates at the vertices.
@LukeAI you can use a tanh() output for angle, and map -1 to 1 as -180 to 180.

Ok thanks for your reflection, good to know that adding outputs would be trivial and there aren't any obvious hidden gotchas. but yeah I don't want to just use regular Yolo for this - finding the vertices in some way or other is important - because I have to infer the perspective of the object and transform it. The application is reading some text on a small rectangle that may be at some difficult angle. In my experience OCR works pretty well if the text is straight on, but poorly otherwise - so I want to detect the corners, and do a perspective transform.

> The application is reading some text on a small rectangle that may be at some difficult angle. In my experience OCR works pretty well if the text is straight on, but poorly otherwise - so I want to detect the corners, and do a perspective transform.

What about 3d-rotated-bboxes?

I don't think it would be more useful for my task, although it might be an interesting thing to implement. (You could generate the ground truth from one of those large camera/lidar road scenes datasets). Getting 3d bounding boxes just from images would be pretty cool. I would try it for this project if I thought that it would converge more easily?

@glenn-jocher 　Sorry to bother you again. I have a question about the loss function code  when calculating the bbox loss. 

 # GIoU
            pxy = torch.sigmoid(ps[:, 0:2])  # pxy = pxy * s - (s - 1) / 2,  s = 1.5  (scale_xy)
            pwh = torch.exp(ps[:, 2:4]).clamp(max=1E3) * anchor_vec[i]
            pbox = torch.cat((pxy, pwh), 1)  # predicted box
            giou = bbox_iou(pbox.t(), tbox[i], x1y1x2y2=False, GIoU=True)  # giou computation
            lbox += (1.0 - giou).sum() if red == 'sum' else (1.0 - giou).mean()  # giou loss
            tobj[b, a, gj, gi] = (1.0 - model.gr) + model.gr * giou.detach().clamp(0).type(tobj.dtype)  

Based on my understanding, the codes above transform the bbox prediction coordinates to yolov3 paper definition format  (tx, ty, tw, th), which are normalization results between 0 and 1.
While  in your tutorial for training custom data model, the required labeled image txt file requires that the bbox coordinates should by normalized by the image width and height. 
I just wonder if the two normalization processes (yolo-paper  definition and  required coordinates label file definition) have the same results? If it is not, do we need to transform the label file? 
Because I just want to train my own car classification model based on your project, I found that some relevant open-source datasets did not follow the coordinate definition required by your project. Some are x1y1x2y2 format. It is OK because I noticed that in your utils.py, you have a x1y1x2y2 to xywh function to transform the coordinate. I just wonder if the two normalization functions regarding to the (x, y) in your codes and the yolo definition are the same?
@glenn-jocher　OK, I understand. Thank you very much for your kind reply.
This issue is stale because it has been open 30 days with no activity. Remove Stale label or comment or this will be closed in 5 days.
